snippet: In the United States, the core inflation rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, is at 1.2 percent over the last 12 months — one of the reasons the Fed may continue to buy bonds.
abstract: Floyd Norris Off The Charts column looks at data showing that inflation rates, both in the United States and around the world, are falling to levels lower than any seen in recent years; notes that decline in inflation measure could provide reason for Federal Reserve to delay widely expected tapering of bond purchases.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, the core inflation rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, is at 1.2 percent over the last 12 months — one of the reasons the Fed may continue to buy bonds.

headline.print_headline: Around the World, Inflation Is Falling To Levels Not Seen for Years
